Company2Name: Wisconsin Electric Power Company d/b/a We Energies

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Description and Regulated Substances

The Oak Creek Power Plant, a coal-fired electric generating facility, constructed a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) air pollution control system to control emissions of nitrogen oxides. The SCR system utilizes 29% aqueous ammonia which is injected into the flue gas (exhaust gas) from the boiler system. The ammonia reacts with the nitrogen oxides to form harmless nitrogen gas and water vapor. The SCR system contains more than 20,000 pounds of aqueous ammonia at a concentration greater than 20% which requires the facility to comply with the U.S. EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulations under 40 CFR Part 68. Oak Creek Power Plant is subject to the Program 2 RMP requirements.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

Releases from the ammonia storage tanks (which are diked) and associated piping were evaluated as required by the RMP regulations. The diked storage tanks would minimize the pooled surface area created by a release, thereby reducing the amount of ammonia that could be released into the atmosphere. A worst-case release of aqueous ammonia from a single storage tank and associated piping within the diked containment was estimated using the ALOHA (Aerial Locations of Hazardous Atmospheres) Air Dispersion Modeling Software program developed by U.S. EPA and NOAA. An alternative-case release scenario involves the rupture or uncoupling of a tanker truck transfer hose during delivery was also estimated using the ALOHA model. Administrative controls, such as loading and tank filling procedures, are in place to limit the quantity of ammonia that could be released. 



Emergency Response Program

The facility's prevention and emergency response plan includes the implementation of U.S. EPA's RMP regulations, OSHA safety programs, and emergency response procedures developed specifically for the facility by the company and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). Oa

k Creek Power Plant is a non-responding facility. The facility personnel are trained to initiate emergency response requirements.



Five-Year Accident History

The facility has not experienced any incidents involving the aqueous ammonia system within the past 5 years.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Continuing employee safety training will help to ensure the ongoing commitment to continual safety improvements. It is We Energies' policy to not only adhere to all applicable Federal, State and Local laws, regulations, and ordinances governing the use of this substance, but to extend safety, health, and environmental efforts beyond that of government requirements. Therefore, We Energies is committed to the safety and health of its employees and the well being of our community. Oak Creek Power Plant finds support from the internal corporate safety, health, and environmental staff as well as a number of professional outside consultants.
